pageTitle: BMW motorcycle locks, luggage, windshields, instruments
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {5282=       A source for numbered luggage keys:  Larry Stonestreet, dba Stoner's Beemer Stash            Ca.stoner@yahoo.com  or (951) 813-1704 8:00 a.m. to 6 p.m. PST.        Motobins.co.uk   also has keys  , 1719=For information on fuel caps and their locks, see article 1B. © Copyright, 2014, R. Fleischer, 28230=Another source for the luggage keys:  Larry Stonestreet, dba Stoner's Beemer Stash   Ca.stoner@yahoo.com  or (951) 813-1704 8:00 a.m. to 6 p.m. PST.      Note that key numbers may or may not start with a zero.  Note that BMW has superceded the earliest part numbers a couple of times.  ALL are listed below, as are a couple of photos of the types of keys.       , 39523=      For large round plastic head mirrors, as from the 1985-1987 R80:  They have LONG threaded stems       for the RIGHT side, fitting the master cylinder mount; and the LEFT side has a shorter thread to fit the       clutch lever perch.   These are nice, don't vibrate much, lighter than the metal types.         51-16-1-452-417 black, left.    51-16-1-452-418 black, right., 41843=The colors on the face of the instruments vary with some years and models.  BMW used white numbers for many years.  1977 models had red needles, blah blah.    For some of these differences, in depth:          http://bmwmotorcycletech.info/models.htm, 41317=BMW purposely calibrates its speedometers to never read slower than the actual speed the motorcycle is traveling at; taking into account tire variations, temperature, instrument changes with conditions, and so on.  BMW has a bulletin on this, #2756, dated 10-21-1996.    The bulletin states that the MAXIMUM amount the speedometer will read fast is:  10% of true speed, PLUS 2.4 mph., 45063=© Copyright, 2014, R. Fleischer, 40100=      note:  Early airheads can use 1998 R1200C mirrors.  , 26465=Here are friendly and helpful locksmiths named Trudy and Alex (and their white dog Maggie).  They have quite a collection of the 3-digit coded keys for various BMW item locks, even has a ring of masters to attempt to make copies of any that they does not have a supply of.   Lots of vintage keys, knowledge, etc.  Key Kraft   1585 Church Street at 28th Street;  San Francisco, CA 94131   (415) 285-0134   Open Monday through Friday 9:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.  }
textBeforeTable: Another source for the luggage keys:  Larry Stonestreet, dba Stoner's Beemer Stash   Ca.stoner@yahoo.com  or (951) 813-1704 8:00 a.m. to 6 p.m. PST.      Note that key numbers may or may not start with a zero.  Note that BMW has superceded the earliest part numbers a couple of times.  ALL are listed below, as are a couple of photos of the types of keys.        BMW does not stock, nor have available, all the various old keys anymore.  Keys in BMW stock are likely to not be made again, and you will have to purchase new lock assemblies.   I have obtained some information on SOME of the OLD keys, superceded numbers. MANY of these keys ARE AVAILABLE from dealerships, for special order; and, many old dealerships have assortments of keys.  Get the lock number off your lock, or key, and see your dealership.  If you do a search, you will find that a S150 key may be shown as an obsolete BMW number 46-54-1-237-764.  You can ask the old-time dealers for keys.  Available from Krauser in Germany, $$$.  See much earlier in this article. Key numbers apply to the BMW flat latches and one system of the Krauser top latches and Krauser BMW-style flat rear latch.  Here is a hyperlink to a How-To article, where someone replaces bad Krauser luggage locks with hardware store items: http://www.vintagebmw.org/v7/node/6637
